results.title: Antarctica
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Quantum”.
Explains Australia’s involvement in the setting up of research bases in Antarctica. Major research at the bases is looked at. Shows auroras and cosmic rays research at Mawson as well as Glaciology studies at Casey and animal studies at Davis.

results.title: The Bat and the rainbow
results.creator_credit: Educational Media Australia, David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Australian National University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Aboriginal legends”.
The Bat’s wife was stolen from him by Rainbow. To get her back Bat mortally wounds the sleeping Rainbow. Bleeding badly, Rainbow rolls into the waterhole where he can still be found. Occasionally, during wet weather, Rainbow rises from the waterhole and stretches his handsome body across the sky. This title is also available in a compilation with two other legends under the title “Aboriginal legends. No. 3” Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Educational Media Australia, David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Australian National University

results.title: Why the emu cannot fly
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson, Educational Media Australia and Australian National University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Aboriginal legends”.
This film is illustrated by drawings of an Aboriginal legend from the book “Djugurba: tales from the Spirit Time” and tells how the emu’s vanity about his beautiful wings brings about his downfall.

results.title: Inganarr the giant serpent
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson, Educational Media Australia and Australian National University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Aboriginal legends”.
A serpent with an enormous appetite, Inganarr, ate all the people of North Goulburn Island and then proceeded to eat the people of Arnhem Land. Fortunately Inganarr suffered from indigestion due to his gluttony and the tribespeople poured out of his mouth in droves. This helps to explain why there are people in eastern Arnhem Land but no people in western Arnhem Land. This film is also available as a compilation film entitled Aboriginal legends no. 3. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

group_works.title: Bermuda, Bahama, Jamaica
group_works.creator_credit: Peter Teneyck and Video Trip Corporation

results.title: Bermuda, Bahama, Jamaica
results.creator_credit: Peter Teneyck and Video Trip Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rand McNally video visit trips”.
Tricia Springer takes you on a tour of three exotic ports of call in the Caribbean. Behind the picture postcard beauty of Bermuda is an island filled with activity, and British tradition. Turquoise waters and natural beauty await you in the Bahamas, which has a vital night life of discos, casinos and Las Vegas style shows. Jamaica is truly West Indian and is permeated by the calypso and reggae beats. Included are bonus tips on getting there, accommodation, food, special events, clothing and climate.

results.title: 3,900 million and one
results.creator_credit: Anthony Mayer, Oxfam and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World around us”.
Examines the way of life of a farming family living in the south of India. Provides an insight into the benefits and problems associated with the extended family system in rural India.

group_siblings.title: The Living forest
group_siblings.creator_credit: Suzanne Gibbs, Christopher Parsons and BBC-TV

results.title: The Living forest
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Gibbs, Christopher Parsons and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World around us”.
The New Forest stands at the crossroads. For 900 years it has remained relatively unspoiled, providing a refuge for shyer animals such as badgers, deer and foxes. But the combined pressures of thousands of visitors keen to “get back to nature” plus the harvesting of trees are threatening the forest’s very existence.
